thread.title: Immigration raids netted 13 in and around St. Louis
thread.title_full: Immigration raids netted 13 in and around St. Louis

author: Robert Patrick St. Louis Post-Dispatch
title: Immigration raids netted 13 in and around St. Louis

organizations.name: st. louis close associated press  file

text:
Close Associated Press 
FILE - In this Wednesday, Feb. 8, 2017, file photo, Guadalupe Garcia de Rayos is locked in a van that is stopped in the street by protesters outside the Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Phoenix. Advocacy groups said that Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers are rounding up people in large numbers around the country as part of stepped-up enforcement under President Donald Trump. The government said it's simply enforcing the laws and taking dangerous immigrants off the streets. On Wednesday, de Rayos showed up at the ICE building in Phoenix for a scheduled check-in with immigration officers and was swiftly deported to Mexico. (Rob Schumacher/The Arizona Republic via AP, File) Immigration raids netted 13 in and around St. Louis ( … ) Associated Press 
FILE - In this Wednesday, Feb. 8, 2017, file photo, Guadalupe Garcia de Rayos is locked in a van that is stopped in the street by protesters outside the Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Phoenix. Advocacy groups said that Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers are rounding up people in large numbers around the country as part of stepped-up enforcement under President Donald Trump. The government said it's simply enforcing the laws and taking dangerous immigrants off the streets. On Wednesday, de Rayos showed up at the ICE building in Phoenix for a scheduled check-in with immigration officers and was swiftly deported to Mexico. (Rob Schumacher/The Arizona Republic via AP, File) 
ST. LOUIS • A controversial series of recent Immigration and Customs Enforcement arrests netted 13 men in and around the agency’s St. Louis suboffice, a spokeswoman said Friday. 
The “enforcement operations” were launched last week, and immediately prompted fears of a new initiative to round up undocumented immigrants. 
But officials said that it was routine operation to target “criminal aliens” and those who entered the country after having been deported. 
Of the St. Louis area arrests, nine men had convictions for crimes, including assault, battery, DUI, sale of a controlled substance, domestic assault and leaving the scene of an accident, according to ICE spokeswoman Gail Montenegro in an email response to Post-Dispatch questions. 
Three had previously been deported and had illegally re-entered the U.S., she wrote. 
Seven of those detained hailed from Mexico, three were from Guatemala, two from El Salvador and one came from Cuba, Montenegro said. Five were arrested in St. Louis and two were arrested in Caseyville. The others were single arrests ranging from Malden, Mo., in Dunklin County, to Champaign, Ill. 
“Every day, as part of routine operations, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Fugitive Operations teams target and arrest criminal aliens and other individuals who are in violation of our nation’s immigration laws,” Montenegro wrote. 
In Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, Wisconsin, Kentucky and Kansas, 235 foreign nationals were arrested, the agency said. Of those, 163 had criminal convictions, 60 had been previously removed from the U.S. And 12 were “immigration fugitives with outstanding final orders of removal issued by a federal immigration judge.” Tags
